conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start moving simultaneously from rest, from the same position, and in the same direction. Their motion is represented on a v-t graph.
For particle A: The velocity increases linearly from 0 to 2v₀ during the time interval 0 to t₀. The velocity decreases linearly from 2v₀ to 0 during the time interval t₀ to 3t₀.
For particle B: The velocity increases linearly from 0 to v₀ during the time interval 0 to 5t₀. The velocity decreases linearly from v₀ to 0 during the time interval 5t₀ to 6t₀.
In a v-t graph, the slope of the line represents acceleration. Acceleration is calculated as the change in velocity divided by the change in time (Δv/Δt).

premise: For particle A: The velocity increases linearly from 0 to 2v₀ during the time interval 0 to t₀.
conclusion: The acceleration of particle A during the time interval 0 to t₀ is a_A1 = (2v₀ - 0)/(t₀ - 0) = 2v₀/t₀.

premise: For particle A: The velocity decreases linearly from 2v₀ to 0 during the time interval t₀ to 3t₀.
conclusion: The deceleration of particle A during the time interval t₀ to 3t₀ is a_A2 = (0 - 2v₀)/(3t₀ - t₀) = -2v₀/2t₀ = -v₀/t₀.

premise: For particle B: The velocity increases linearly from 0 to v₀ during the time interval 0 to 5t₀.
conclusion: The acceleration of particle B during the time interval 0 to 5t₀ is a_B1 = (v₀ - 0)/(5t₀ - 0) = v₀/5t₀.

premise: For particle B: The velocity decreases linearly from v₀ to 0 during the time interval 5t₀ to 6t₀.
conclusion: The deceleration of particle B during the time interval 5t₀ to 6t₀ is a_B2 = (0 - v₀)/(6t₀ - 5t₀) = -v₀/t₀.

premise: The magnitudes of deceleration for particle A and particle B are |a_A2| = v₀/t₀ and |a_B2| = v₀/t₀, respectively.
conclusion: The ratio of the magnitudes of deceleration for particle A and particle B is |a_A2|/|a_B2| = (v₀/t₀)/(v₀/t₀) = 1.

premise: The ratio of the magnitudes of deceleration for particle A and particle B is 1.
conclusion: The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B during their deceleration phases is 1:1.
